pageData.text: In this investigation, you will learn about the energy levels, <button class='glossary-text'>sublevels</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>orbitals</button> of atoms. After learning about how <button class='glossary-text'>Hund’s Rule</button>, Pauli’s Exclusion Principle and the <button class='glossary-text'>Aufbau Principle</button> describe the organization of electrons, you will construct orbital diagrams and <button class='glossary-text'>electron configurations</button> of elements from the periodic table.

text: Describe the energy levels, <button class='glossary-text'>sublevels</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>orbitals</button> of atoms.
Apply <button class='glossary-text'>Hund’s Rule</button>, Pauli’s Exclusion Principle and the <button class='glossary-text'>Aufbau Principle</button> to construct orbital diagrams.
Construct <button class='glossary-text'>electron configurations</button> and orbital diagrams for atoms using the periodic table.

pageData.text: Many holidays are celebrated with fireworks that illuminate the sky with a variety of colored lights. The metal ions in fireworks are chosen specifically to create the assortment of observed colors. This colored light is produced by excitation and subsequent relaxation of the electrons in the metals.

Light emission by atoms is a foundational principle of quantum chemistry. Atoms contain electrons that occupy discrete energy levels. The actual energy of each state (level) depends upon several factors: the nuclear charge, the distance of the electron from the nucleus, and the number of other electrons between the nucleus and the electron of interest.

pageData.desc: A well-tray containing various metal salts, each ignited and producing a different colored flame.
pageData.altText: A well-tray containing various metal salts, each ignited and producing a different colored flame.

pageData.subTitle: Electron Energy Levels
pageData.text: When sunlight passes through a prism or crystal, the light separates into a continuous spectrum. This phenomenon occurs naturally when sunlight passes through raindrops to create rainbows. These colors make up the only part of the electromagnetic spectrum we can see naturally. When an element is heated and its light emission passed through a prism, the spectrum produced is not continuous. Rather this <button class='glossary-text'>atomic spectrum</button> consists of lines of different colors, or wavelengths of light, that are unique to each element.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: A diagram showing how when an element is heated it produces light which, when passed through a prism, splits into distinct wavelengths of light known also known as its atomic spectrum.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: A diagram showing how when an element is heated it produces light which, when passed through a prism, splits into distinct wavelengths of light known also known as its atomic spectrum.

pageData.text: In an atom, each electron has a specific energy called its energy level. Electrons in the lowest energy level are generally closest to the nucleus, and this level is assigned a <button class='glossary-text'>principal quantum number (n)</button> of 1. As electrons increase in energy, they are found at higher energy levels (ex: n = 2, n = 3) further from the nucleus. Electron energy levels are much like steps on a staircase. Each step represents a specific energy value. Electrons can exist at each energy level, but not at a level in between.

The lowest energy level is the first step, the next highest energy level is the second step, and so on. The analogy continues when we observe that it takes less energy to reach the first step than the other higher steps. But try as you might, you cannot stand in the space between steps. This separation of electron energy levels into discrete values means electron energy is quantized. Note that unlike an actual staircase, the differences between energy levels are inconsistent.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: A diagram of a staircase with the first step labeled n equals one, the second step labeled n equals two, the third step labeled n equals three and the fourth step labeled n equals four. An arrow pointing up along the stair is labeled increasing energy.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A diagram of a staircase with the first step labeled n equals one, the second step labeled n equals two, the third step labeled n equals three and the fourth step labeled n equals four. An arrow pointing up along the stair is labeled increasing energy.

pageData.text: Electrons have different states depending on the energy levels they occupy. Electrons in the lowest energy level are in their <button class='glossary-text'>ground state</button>. Electrons falling to the ground state from a higher level lose energy by emitting electromagnetic radiation (energy) equal to the difference between the energy levels. Electrons can absorb energy to reach an <button class='glossary-text'>excited state</button> at higher energy levels. The energy absorption must equal the difference between the current energy level and the next energy level.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Two illustrations of atoms with one electron. The first atom has an electron in an excited state emitting energy to fall to a ground state. The second atom has an electron in a ground state absorbing energy to reach an excited state.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Two illustrations of atoms with one electron. The first atom has an electron in an excited state emitting energy to fall to a ground state. The second atom has an electron in a ground state absorbing energy to reach an excited state.

pageData.question: Under which of the following conditions would an electron in an excited state transition into a ground state?

options.text: The electron transfers energy to another electron.
The electron divides into an atomic spectrum.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: When an electron emits energy, it falls from an excited state to a ground state.

pageData.question: An electron in a ground state would be found at which of the following atomic energy levels?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Electrons at the lowest energy level, n = 1, are in a ground state.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In an atom, each electron has a specific energy called its energy level. Electrons in the lowest energy level are generally closest to the nucleus, and this level is assigned a principal quantum number (n) of 1. As electrons increase in energy, they are found at higher energy levels (ex: n = 2, n = 3) further from the nucleus. Electron energy levels are much like steps on a staircase. Each step represents a specific energy value. Electrons can exist at each energy level, but not at a level in between. Electrons have different states depending on the energy levels they occupy. Electrons in the lowest energy level are in their ground state. Electrons falling to the ground state from a higher level lose energy by emitting electromagnetic radiation (energy) equal to the difference between the energy levels. Electrons can absorb energy to reach an excited state at higher energy levels. The energy absorption must equal the difference between the current energy level and the next energy level.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In an atom, each electron has a specific energy called its energy level. Electrons in the lowest energy level are generally closest to the nucleus, and this level is assigned a principal quantum number (n) of 1. As electrons increase in energy, they are found at higher energy levels (ex: n = 2, n = 3) further from the nucleus. Electron energy levels are much like steps on a staircase. Each step represents a specific energy value. Electrons can exist at each energy level, but not at a level in between. Electrons have different states depending on the energy levels they occupy. Electrons in the lowest energy level are in their ground state. Electrons falling to the ground state from a higher level lose energy by emitting electromagnetic radiation (energy) equal to the difference between the energy levels. Electrons can absorb energy to reach an excited state at higher energy levels. The energy absorption must equal the difference between the current energy level and the next energy level.

img.alt: Figure 3: Two illustrations of atoms with one electron. The first atom has an electron in an excited state emitting energy to fall to a ground state. The second atom has an electron in a ground state absorbing energy to reach an excited state.

pageData.text: When electrons occupy an energy level they do so in only certain amounts. The lower energy levels can only support a couple electrons, while higher energy levels can hold more. You can calculate the maximum number of electrons that can exist in an energy level by taking two times the square of the . 2n2

Each energy level contains of electrons with the same energy. The sublevels are assigned the letters s, p, d, and f. The number of sublevels within an energy level is equal to the principal quantum number: the first energy level (n = 1) has only one sublevel (1s), the second energy level (n = 2) has two sublevels (2s and 2p), and so on as shown in Figure 4.

Within each energy level, the sublevels are arranged according to energy level, with the s sublevel having the lowest energy. If there is more than one sublevel, the sublevels are arranged as follows from lowest to highest energy:
s < p < d < f

Just as there is a maximum number of electrons that can occupy each energy level, there is a maximum number of electrons that can occupy each sublevel. An s sublevel holds one or two electrons; the p sublevel holds up to six; the d sublevel holds up to 10; and the f sublevel holds up to 14 electrons.

pageData.desc: A diagram with the y axis labeled increasing energy and four rows labeled from bottom to top shell one, shell two, shell three and shell four. On the row shell one a box to the far left is labeled one s. On the row shell two a box in the far left is labeled two s and a group a three boxes to the right of the first box is labeled two p. On the row shell three a box to the far left is labeled three s, a group of boxes to the right are labeled three p, and a group of five boxes to the right of the group of three are labeled three d. On the row shell four a box to the far left is labeled four s, a group of three boxes to the right is labeled four p, a group of five boxes more to the right is labeled four d and a group of seven boxes to the right of the group of five is labeled four f.
pageData.altText: A diagram with the y axis labeled increasing energy and four rows labeled from bottom to top shell one, shell two, shell three and shell four. On the row shell one a box to the far left is labeled one s. On the row shell two a box in the far left is labeled two s and a group a three boxes to the right of the first box is labeled two p. On the row shell three a box to the far left is labeled three s, a group of boxes to the right are labeled three p, and a group of five boxes to the right of the group of three are labeled three d. On the row shell four a box to the far left is labeled four s, a group of three boxes to the right is labeled four p, a group of five boxes more to the right is labeled four d and a group of seven boxes to the right of the group of five is labeled four f.

pageData.subTitle: Orbitals
pageData.text: The location of electrons around a nucleus is described in terms of probability, since there is no way for scientists to know their exact location in an atom. A region in an atom where there is the highest probability of finding an electron is called an <button class='glossary-text'>orbital</button>. This is similar to how there is a high probability of finding you at home, but occasionally you may be found outside the home to see a friend or go to work.

Any orbital can have a maximum of two electrons. <button class='glossary-text'>Hund’s rule</button> states that an orbital must be singly occupied before it can be doubly occupied. When an orbital does contain two electrons, the electrons must have opposite spins. This is known as the <button class='glossary-text'>Pauli exclusion principle</button>. As electrons fill multiple orbitals, the <button class='glossary-text'>Aufbau principle</button> states that electrons must occupy the lowest available energy levels before occupying higher ones.

pageData.question: An atom has an orbital containing two electrons, each with the same spin. This atom violates which of the following principles?

options.text: The atom does not violate any principles.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The atom violates the Pauli exclusion principle, which describes how two electrons occupying the same orbital will spin in opposite directions of one another.

pageData.question: Which of the following describes how an electron will not occupy the third energy level until the sublevels of the two lower energy levels are filled?

options.text: the Law of Conservation of Mass

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The Aufbau principle describes how an electron will fill the lowest energy sublevels before filling any higher energy sublevels.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Any orbital can have a maximum of two electrons. Hund’s Rule states that an orbital must be singly occupied before it can be doubly occupied. When an orbital does contain two electrons, the electrons must have opposite spins. This is known as the Pauli exclusion principle. As electrons fill multiple orbitals, the Aufbau principle states that electrons must occupy the lowest available energy levels before occupying higher ones.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Any orbital can have a maximum of two electrons. Hund’s Rule states that an orbital must be singly occupied before it can be doubly occupied. When an orbital does contain two electrons, the electrons must have opposite spins. This is known as the Pauli exclusion principle. As electrons fill multiple orbitals, the Aufbau principle states that electrons must occupy the lowest available energy levels before occupying higher ones.

pageData.text: Within an energy level, a is comprised of of the same type. For example, there is an s orbital in an s sublevel, there are p orbitals in a p sublevel, and so on. Each orbital can hold one or two electrons, but a sublevel may contain more than one orbital.

The different types of orbitals each have a unique shape. An s orbital has a spherical shape. Each s sublevel has only one s orbital. The size of the spherical s orbital increases for s sublevels at higher energies. A p orbital has a lobe shape. Each p sublevel has three p orbitals allowing the sublevel to hold a maximum of six electrons. These orbitals are arranged in three different axes around the nucleus. Just as with s orbitals, p orbitals for p sublevels at higher energies have the same shape but a larger volume as the energy level increases. The d and f orbitals have complex lobe and disc shapes. Each d sublevel has five d orbitals allowing the sublevel to hold a maximum of ten electrons; each f sublevel has seven f orbitals for a maximum occupancy of fourteen electrons.

pageData.subTitle: Electron Configuration
pageData.text: The periodic table arranges atomic numbers in order of increasing <button class='glossary-text'>sublevel</button> energy. In Figure 5, you can see that different blocks of the table correspond to different sublevels. The sublevel block in which an element is found represents the highest energy sublevel occupied by the electrons of the element.

Except for the d and f sublevel blocks, the period (row) number of the periodic table corresponds to the highest energy level occupied by an element’s electrons. For example, oxygen is found in the p block in Period 2 and therefore oxygen’s highest-energy electrons are found in the 2p sublevel.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: The periodic table of the elements separated into s, p, d and f sublevel blocks. The s block is made up of hydrogen and helium and the first two elements in periods two through seven. The d block is made up of the third through twelfth elements in periods four through seven. The p block is made up of the last six elements in periods two through seven. The f block is made up of the lanthanides and actinides.
pageData.altText: Figure 5: The periodic table of the elements separated into s, p, d and f sublevel blocks. The s block is made up of hydrogen and helium and the first two elements in periods two through seven. The d block is made up of the third through twelfth elements in periods four through seven. The p block is made up of the last six elements in periods two through seven. The f block is made up of the lanthanides and actinides.

pageData.text: The number of elements within a row of a sublevel block also reveals a pattern in the arrangement of electrons. Notice that the number of elements in a given period of the s sublevel block is two – the same number as the maximum number of electrons that can occupy an s sublevel. The number of elements in a given period of the p sublevel block is six; the d sublevel block has ten elements per period; the f sublevel block has fourteen elements.

The d and f blocks are organized slightly differently than the lower energy s and p sublevel blocks. A particular d sublevel is one less (n - 1) than the period number. A particular f sublevel is two less (n - 2) than the period number. For example, in Period 4, the first d block is the 3d sublevel. In Period 6, the second d block is the 5d sublevel and the first f block is the 4f sublevel (see ).

Period 1 consists of the elements hydrogen (H) and helium (He). These elements have only one sublevel (s) and therefore only one (1s) which is at the lowest energy level. Hydrogen has only one electron while helium has two electrons. The of an atom lists the electrons in order of increasing energy. For helium, the electron configuration is written as: 1s2. You would read this notation as “one s two”. The number of the energy level is written first (1), followed by the sublevel (s), and the number of electrons within the sublevel (2). Table 1 shows the electron configurations for hydrogen and helium.

can also be written using the blocks shown on the periodic table (see ). By counting across and down the periodic table until you reach the element for which you are writing an electron configuration, you can identify the correct number of electrons and their . For example, counting to helium on the periodic table takes you to the second element in Period 1 in the s sublevel block. The electron configuration for helium again is 1s2.

Period 2 starts with lithium (Li), which has three electrons. The first two electrons fill the 1s sublevel, just like in helium, while the third electron goes to the 2s sublevel, the next sublevel with the lowest energy. The electron configuration for lithium is 1s22s1. Note that when writing an electron configuration, all the occupied sublevels are listed starting with the lowest energy sublevels first. The element beryllium (Be) fills sublevels 1s and 2s with its four electrons. The remaining six elements in Period 2 are found in the p sublevel block of the periodic table and begin to fill p orbitals in the second energy level with their additional electrons. Neon (Ne) has all its sublevels (1s, 2s, 2p) filled.

Electron configurations can be abbreviated. Elements further down the periodic table have many electrons and writing the full notation can be time consuming. Since noble gases, such as helium, have all their sublevels filled they can be used to represent some of the sublevels for an element in the next period.

tableData.text: 1s22s12p1
1s22s22p4
1s22s22p6

pageData.text: The elements in Period 3, sodium through argon, have similar to those of the elements in Period 2. The 3s and 3p begin to fill but not the 3d sublevel, which requires electrons to have a much higher energy level and is thus only filled by elements from Period 4 on. Skipping the 3d sublevel is easy to remember if you use the strategy of counting across the periodic table to write your electron configurations.

tableData.text: 1s22s12p63s1
1s22s22p63s23p2
1s22s22p63s23p6

pageData.text: Potassium (K) and calcium (Ca) in Period 4 have their valence electrons in the 4s sublevels, but as we move across the period to elements such as manganese (Mn) and zinc (Zn), the 3d sublevel is filled after the 4s sublevel. Although found at a higher energy level, the 4s sublevel has a slightly lower energy than the 3d sublevel and is thus filled first after the filling of the 3p sublevel at the end of Period 3. The progression through the sublevels resumes as normal with the filling of the 4p sublevel starting with gallium (Ga). This pattern also takes place in Period 5 with the 4d sublevel filled after the 5s sublevel but before the 5p sublevel.

tableData.text: 1s22s22p63s23p64s2
1s22s22p63s23p64s23d5
1s22s22p63s23p64s23d10
1s22s22p63s23p64s23d104p5

pageData.text: Periods 6 and 7 contain some elements with electrons in the 4f and 5f , respectively. Let's determine the for the element cerium (Ce) in Period 6 as an example. Cerium has 58 electrons, 54 of which fill all the sublevels through 4d and 5p in the manner described previously. The next two electrons fill the 6s sublevel as expected. As for the last two electrons, the 4f sublevel has the next lowest energy and so cerium should have its electrons there; however, the 5d and 4f sublevels are so close in energy that one electron occupies a 4f while the other occupies a 5d orbital. Looking at the periodic table for this pattern, we see that in Period 6 there is one element in the 5d block before we reach cerium in the first position of the 4f block.

pageData.desc: Figure 6: A portion of the periodic table from periods six to seven and groups one a to four b with elements fifty-five and fifty-six highlighted in one color and element fifty-eight highlighted in another color. The first two groups are labeled s block, the last three groups are labeled d block, and the two groups shown in the lanthanides and actinides are labeled f block.
pageData.altText: Figure 6: A portion of the periodic table from periods six to seven and groups one a to four b with elements fifty-five and fifty-six highlighted in one color and element fifty-eight highlighted in another color. The first two groups are labeled s block, the last three groups are labeled d block, and the two groups shown in the lanthanides and actinides are labeled f block.

pageData.text: There are some exceptions to the patterns in electron configuration. When a particular d sublevel is either completely filled or half-filled it is very stable, and an element with a certain number of electrons will prefer to keep a d sublevel half-filled even if it means a lower energy sublevel will only be partially filled. Chromium is an example of a stable half-filled d sublevel. Copper is an example of a stable filled d sublevel. Note that in both configurations the 4s sublevel is only half filled in order to achieve d sublevel stability.

pageData.title: Table 5.

tableData.text: 1s22s22p63s23p64s13d5
1s22s22p63s23p64s13d10

pageData.text: To practice determining <button class='glossary-text'>electron configurations</button>, you can use a graphic such Figure 7 to trace the increasing energy <button class='glossary-text'>sublevels</button> from the lowest to highest energy levels.

pageData.desc: Figure 7: 7 rows representing electron energy levels. The first row is n = 1 and has the sublevel 1s. The second row is n = 2 and has the sublevels 2s and 2p. The third row is n = 3 and has the sublevels 3s, 3p and 3d. The fourth row is n = 4 and has the sublevels 4s, 4p, 4d and 4f. The fifth row is n = 5 and has the sublevels 5s, 5p, 5d and 5f. The sixth row is n = 6 and has the sublevels 6s, 6p and 6d. The seventh row is n = 7 and has the sublevels 7s and 7p. 8 arrows are drawn diagonally from top right to bottom left through the sublevels. The first arrow runs through sublevel 1s. The second row runs through sublevel 2s. The third arrow runs through sublevels 2p and 3s. The fourth arrow runs through the sublevels 3p and 4s. The fifth arrow runs through sublevels 3d, 4p and 5s. The sixth arrow runs through the sublevels 4d, 5p and 6s. The seventh arrow runs through the levels 4f, 5d, 6p and 7s. The eighth arrow runs through the sublevels 5f, 6d, and 7p.
pageData.altText: Figure 7: 7 rows representing electron energy levels. The first row is n = 1 and has the sublevel 1s. The second row is n = 2 and has the sublevels 2s and 2p. The third row is n = 3 and has the sublevels 3s, 3p and 3d. The fourth row is n = 4 and has the sublevels 4s, 4p, 4d and 4f. The fifth row is n = 5 and has the sublevels 5s, 5p, 5d and 5f. The sixth row is n = 6 and has the sublevels 6s, 6p and 6d. The seventh row is n = 7 and has the sublevels 7s and 7p. 8 arrows are drawn diagonally from top right to bottom left through the sublevels. The first arrow runs through sublevel 1s. The second row runs through sublevel 2s. The third arrow runs through sublevels 2p and 3s. The fourth arrow runs through the sublevels 3p and 4s. The fifth arrow runs through sublevels 3d, 4p and 5s. The sixth arrow runs through the sublevels 4d, 5p and 6s. The seventh arrow runs through the levels 4f, 5d, 6p and 7s. The eighth arrow runs through the sublevels 5f, 6d, and 7p.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the error in this electron configuration for the element carbon (C)?1s22s12p3

options.text: Not all the sublevels are filled before a higher energy sublevel is occupied.
Some of the sublevels for this element are missing.
This configuration does not list the preceding noble gas.
The number of electrons is incorrect.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The electron configuration given does not have a full 2s orbital and yet there are electrons in the higher energy 2p orbital. This violates the Aufbau principle.

pageData.question: The following electron configuration describes which of the following chemical elements? The Resources icon features a Periodic Table of the Elements.[Ne]3s23p6

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: This electron configuration describes an element with three full electron energy levels, which is the noble gas argon (Ar).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Carbon has six total electrons. Two electrons will fill the 1s orbital, then two electrons will fill the next highest orbital after that, 2s. This leaves two final electrons to occupy part of the next highest orbital, 2p. Note that when writing an electron configuration, all the occupied sublevels are listed starting with the lowest energy sublevels first. The electron configuration for carbon is 1s22s22p2. Electron configurations can be abbreviated. Elements further down the periodic table have many electrons and writing the full notation can be time consuming. Since noble gases, such as helium, have all their sublevels filled they can be used to represent some of the sublevels for an element in the next period.

This leaves two final electrons to occupy part of the next highest orbital, 2p. Note that when writing an electron configuration, all the occupied sublevels are listed starting with the lowest energy sublevels first. The electron configuration for carbon is 1s22s22p2. Electron configurations can be abbreviated. Elements further down the periodic table have many electrons and writing the full notation can be time consuming. Since noble gases, such as helium, have all their sublevels filled they can be used to represent some of the sublevels for an element in the next period.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: An electron in which sublevel would have a higher energy than an electron in the 4s sublevel?
Which of the following sublevels can hold a maximum of ten electrons?
How many orbitals are found in any p sublevel?
An electron energy level with the principal quantum number (n) of 3 can hold how many electrons and has how many sublevels?
Which sublevel has the highest energy?

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.

In this activity, you will select elements from the periodic table for which to construct <button class='glossary-text'>electron configurations</button>. Each element is worth a different point value: to finish the activity, complete enough elements to reach 30 points. The simulation can be found after the protocol for the activity.

From the periodic table in the simulation, select an element for which you would like to write an <button class='glossary-text'>electron configuration</button>. The point values of each element are color coded in a key in the bottom left corner.

Earn points for your chosen element by answering the associated question. These questions will either be multiple-choice or sequencing. When determining electron configurations for elements in Periods 6 and higher, you must provide idealized configurations rather than observed ones.
When you have earned 30 points, you will gain access to your results. From here, you can see which questions you answered correctly before saving your results to submit to your instructor.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: A portion of the periodic table from periods six to seven and groups one a to four b with elements fifty-five and fifty-six highlighted in one color and element fifty-eight highlighted in another color. The first two groups are labeled s block, the last three groups are labeled d block, and the two groups shown in the lanthanides and actinides are labeled f block.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: 7 rows representing electron energy levels. The first row is n = 1 and has the sublevel 1s. The second row is n = 2 and has the sublevels 2s and 2p. The third row is n = 3 and has the sublevels 3s, 3p and 3d. The fourth row is n = 4 and has the sublevels 4s, 4p, 4d and 4f. The fifth row is n = 5 and has the sublevels 5s, 5p, 5d and 5f. The sixth row is n = 6 and has the sublevels 6s, 6p and 6d. The seventh row is n = 7 and has the sublevels 7s and 7p. 8 arrows are drawn diagonally from top right to bottom left through the sublevels. The first arrow runs through sublevel 1s. The second row runs through sublevel 2s. The third arrow runs through sublevels 2p and 3s. The fourth arrow runs through the sublevels 3p and 4s. The fifth arrow runs through sublevels 3d, 4p and 5s. The sixth arrow runs through the sublevels 4d, 5p and 6s. The seventh arrow runs through the levels 4f, 5d, 6p and 7s. The eighth arrow runs through the sublevels 5f, 6d, and 7p.
pageData.content: Figure 7. Pattern for organizing electron energy sublevels

data.title: Atomic spectrum
data.content: The spectrum of frequencies of electromagnetic radiation emitted due to an electron making a transition from a high energy state to a lower energy state.

data.title: Aufbau principle
data.content: States that electrons must occupy the lowest available energy levels before occupying higher ones.

data.title: Electron configuration
data.content: A description of the electrons of an atom in order of increasing energy.

data.title: Excited state
data.content: An energy state of an atom or other particle, such as an electron, that is higher than its ground state.

data.title: Ground state
data.content: The lowest energy state of an atom or other particle, such as an electron.

data.title: Hund's rule
data.content: States that an orbital must be singly occupied before it can be doubly occupied.

data.title: Orbital
data.content: The regions within an energy sublevel that an electron is most likely to occupy.

data.title: Pauli exclusion principle
data.content: States that when an orbital does contain two electrons, the electrons must have opposite spins.

data.title: Principal quantum number (n)
data.content: Describes the main energy level occupied by an electron.

data.title: Sublevel
data.content: An energy level within a main energy level occupied by an electron and which contains orbitals.
